characters: HE GRINS ALL OVER AND SAYS
SHOOTING DOWN LENGTH OF CITY ROOM

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Two telephone operators sit at switchboard busy plugging and out answering calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the Morning Post... The City  Room? Just a moment, I'll connect  you. (plugs in call)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning Post... Sports Department?  Just a moment -- (plugs in call)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to disclose the rest of the anteroom. T Camera left are the elevators -- at back wall directly be switchboard are chairs and a table for visitors. Next to  switchboard are stairs leading downward to the next floor waist-high iron grill with a gate in it separates the  switchboard from the anteroom, a similar grill separating again from the city room which stretches on beyond  switchboard. At a table in the switchboard enclosure sits office boy, about fifteen, doing a crossword puzzle. The clock on the back wall shows that it is nearly one o'cloc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he bends over paper. We catch a glimpse of the squares a crossword puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as a reporter comes out of the City Room, clanging gate t behind him. The office boy looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a seven-letter word for --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ask me! If I knew any seven- letter words, I'd be something better  than a reporter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He catches a glimpse of the far elevator going down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Down! Down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as reporter runs in to the closed elevator door and pound on it. It comes back, the door opens, and he gets in. The door closes, as elevator goes down. The near elevator com up and discharges Hildy Johnson and Bruce Baldwin. Bruce  carries an umbrella and wears a raincoat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: office boy looking over his puzzle as Hildy and Bruce com into the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile) Hello, Skinny. Remember me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up; then a  glowing smile) Hildy Johnson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy approaches the switchboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to operator) Hello, Maisie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first operator looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello -- Hildy! You coming back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, just visiting. Tell me, is the  lord of the universe in today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is -- and in a very bad humor. I  think somebody stole one of his crown  jewels. Shall I announce you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, never mind -- I'll blow my own  trumpet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy turns to Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be more than ten minutes, I  promise you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even ten minutes is a long time to  be away from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a giggle off scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks towards Bruce and Hildy and giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say, Bruce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce, embarrassed, looks at the office boy, then looks b at Hildy as they turn toward second gate leading into Cit Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said -- uh -- I said even ten  minutes -- is a long time -- to be  away from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be embarrassed, Bruce. I heard  it, but I just wanted to hear it  again. I can stand being spoiled a  little. The gentleman I'm going to  have a chat with did very little  spoiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) I'd like to spoil him just once.  Sure you don't want me to go in with  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My job, Bruce. I started it -- and  I'll finish it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you're right -- but if it  gets rough, remember I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come a-running, pardner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to push open the iron-grilled gate leading int the City Room. Bruce quickly springs forward and opens it for her. Hildy smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses his cheek and walks through. He looks after he The office boy whistles. Bruce pays no attention, but sta after Hildy.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING DOWN LENGTH OF CITY ROOM
dialogues.text: Hildy starts to walk through City Room.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: as she walks the length of the City Room. It's a long wal because it's a room that takes up practically the whole f The scene is a busy one. But, gradually, as Hildy starts  down, one after another recognize her. There are cries of "Hildy!" "Hello, Hildy", etc., from the men as Hildy goes straight down the aisle. She never stops but waves her ow greetings: "Jim!" "Hi, good-looking!" "Laura" "Hullo, Pop "Nan!" "Eddie!" "Hello, Mac" "Pete!" "Frank" "Oscar!", an gets responses from each of them. One man is bent over hi desk reading his copy -- he is standing up. Hildy slaps h as she goes by. He turns around: "Say, who did that?" As sees Hildy: "Hello, Hildy!" Hildy: "Hi, Jake." She passes middle-aged woman, almost an Edna May Oliver type, seated a desk pounding out copy and smoking a cigarette. As Hild comes up to her she slaps the woman on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Beatrice. How's "Advice to  the Lovelorn"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) Hildy! I'll be a monkey's uncle!  What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Point of information -- what does a  girl say on meeting her divorced  husband? OR: (What does a girl do,  etc.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (illustrating) My advice is duck and cross with  your right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy moves on. CAMERA TRUCKS WITH HER to the end of the  room where she pauses before the frosted glass partition  which separates Walter Burns' office from the rest of the City Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she opens the door. Burns is shaving with an electric  razor and Louie is holding the mirror up in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shaving, Louie holding the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little more round the chin, Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a sound of the door closing and Burns, without  looking up, says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, I'm surprised, Mr. Burns. That's  no way to talk to your wife -- even  if she's no longer your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Hello, Hildy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Walter. (to Louie) Hi, Louie -- how's the slotmachine  king?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I ain't doing that any more. I'm  retired. I'm one of you fellas now --  a newspaper man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Editorials?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get going, Louie. I got company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door flies open and Duffy comes busting in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm busy, Duffy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're not too busy to know  that the Governor hasn't signed that  reprieve!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that means Earl Williams dies  tomorrow morning and makes a sucker  out of us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy. Where's Mac?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on my phone. He just called me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't do that to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs the phone on his desk:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me that call on Duffy's wire!  Hello -- Mac? Burns. Where's the  Governor? -- What do you mean, you  can't locate him? (apparently pleading  to the one man in  the world who can  help him) Mac, you know what this means. We're  the only paper in town defending  Earl Williams and if he hangs tomorrow  we're washed up! Find the Governor  and when you find him tell him we  want that reprieve!... Tell him I  elected him and I can have him  impeached! Sure, you can do it, Mac --  I know you can. I always said you  were the greatest reporter in the  country and now you can prove it.  Get going! Attaboy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Duffy,  sarcastically) The greatest reporter in the country!  First I gotta tell him what news to  get! Gotta tell him how to get it --  then I gotta write it for him  afterward! Now if you were a decent  City Editor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with Louie and Hildy in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't blame me. I'm City Editor in  name only. You do all the hiring  around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! Well, I do the firing, too.  Remember that, Duffy, and Keep a  civil tongue in your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like to interfere with  business, but would you boys pardon  us while we have a little heart-to- heart talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (together) Well -- But I gotta --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at Burns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scram, you guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't miss anything. You'll  probably be able to hear him just as  well outside as here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: going out of the door. They cast an interested look back linger a second. Over scene comes Burns' voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said scram!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They close the door hurriedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I have a cigarette, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burns reaches into his pocket, extracts a cigarette and t it on the desk. Hildy reaches for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. A match?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burns delves into pockets again, comes up with matchbox,  tosses it to Hildy, who catches it deftly, and strikes th match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy finishes lighting her cigarette, takes a puff, and  fans out the match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long is what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what. How long since we've  seen each other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see. I was in Reno six weeks --  then Bermuda... Oh, about four months,  I guess. Seems like yesterday to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slyly) Maybe it was yesterday. Been seeing  me in your dreams?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually) No -- Mama doesn't dream about you  any more, Walter. You wouldn't know  the old girl now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with conviction) Oh, yes I would. I'd know you any  time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grows lyrical and, rising from his seat, is about to s toward her, as he continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (together) -- any place, anywhere --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half-pityingly) You're repeating yourself! That's  the speech you made the night you  proposed. (she burlesques his  fervor) "-- any time -- any place --  anywhere!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (growling) I notice you still remember it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll always remember it. If I hadn't  remembered it, I wouldn't have  divorced you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Hildy, I sort of wish you  hadn't done it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Divorced me. It sort of makes a fellow  lose faith in himself. It almost  gives him a feeling he wasn't wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy mackerel! Look, Walter, that's  what divorces are for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense. You've got the old-fashioned  idea that divorces are something  that last forever -- till 'death us  do part'. Why, a divorce doesn't  mean anything today. It's only a few  words mumbled over you by a judge.  We've got something between us nothing  can change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose that's true in a way. I am  fond of you, Walter. I often wish  you weren't such a stinker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, that's a nice thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why did you promise me you  wouldn't fight the divorce and then  try and gum up the whole works?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I meant to let you go -- but,  you know, you never miss the water  till the well runs dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fellow your age, hiring an airplane  to write: (she gestures above  to indicate sky- writing) 'Hildy: Don't be hasty -- remember  my dimple. Walter.! It held things  up twenty minutes while the Judge  ran out to watch it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't want to brag, but I've  still got the dimple -- and in the  same place -- I just acted like any  husband who doesn't want to see his  home broken up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What home? Don't you remember the  home I promised you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes -- we were to have it right  after our honeymoon -- honeymoon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it my fault? Did I know that  coal mine was going to have another  cave-in? I meant to be with you on  our honeymoon, Hildy -- honest I  did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I know is that instead of two  weeks in Atlantic City with my  bridegroom, I spent two weeks in a  coal mine with John Kruptzky -- age  sixty-three -- getting food and air  out of a tube! You don't deny that.  Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deny it! I'm proud of it! We beat  the whole country on that story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, suppose we did? That isn't  what I got married for. What's the  good of -- Look, Walter, I came up  here to tell you that you'll have to  stop phoning me a dozen times a day --  sending twenty telegrams -- all the  rest of it, because I'm --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not fight, Hildy. Tell you  what. You come back to work on the  paper and if we find we can't get  along in a friendly way, we'll get  married again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't any hard feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, you're wonderful in a  loathesome sort of way. Now, would  you mind keeping quiet long enough  for me to tell you what I came up  here for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising, reaching for  his hat) Sure, come on. We'll have some lunch  and you can tell me everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also rising) I have a lunch date. I just want --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can break it, can't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you can. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me what to do! We're  divorced -- I'm a free woman. You're  not my husband and you're not my  boss! And what's more, you're not  going to be my boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what I said. That's what I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you're not coming back to  work here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the first time you've been  right today. That's what I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still interrupting) You've had a better offer, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet I've got a better offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, go on and take it. Work for  somebody else! That's the gratitude  I get for --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Walter, but I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring her) What were you when you came here  five years ago? A little college  girl from a School of Journalism! I  took a little doll-faced mugg --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't have taken me if I hadn't  been doll-faced!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I? I thought it would be  a novelty to have a face around here  a man could look at without  shuddering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Walter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going right on) I made a great reporter out of you,  Hildy, but you won't be half as good  on any other paper, and you know it.  You need me and I need you -- and  the paper needs both of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the paper'll have to learn to  do without me. And so will you. It  just didn't work out, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would have worked if you'd been  satisfied with just being editor and  reporter. But no! You had to marry  me and spoil everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignantly) I wasn't satisfied! I suppose I  proposed to you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you practically did! Making  goo-goo eyes at me for two years  till I broke down. And I still claim  I was tight the night I proposed. If  you'd been a gentleman you'd have  forgotten all about it. But not you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speechless) You -- you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs something and chucks it at him. He ducks. The p rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hildy) You're losing your eye. You used to  be able to pitch better than that. (he reaches for phone) Hello... Yeah... What? Sweeney? Well,  what can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: seated at his desk, talking into phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you? Are you  drunk? This is Duffy, not Sweeney!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burns into phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweeney! You can't do that to me!  Not today, of all days! Jumping  Jehosophat! Oh, no, Sweeney... Well,  I suppose so... All right. If you  have to, you have to. (he hangs up) How do you like that? Everything  happens to me -- with 365 days in  the year -- this has to be the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweeney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. Might just as well be. The  only man on the paper who can write --  and his wife picks this morning to  have a baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweeney? (she laughs) Well, after all, he didn't do it on  purpose, did he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care whether he did or not.  He's supposed to be covering the  Earl Williams case and there he is --  waiting at the hospital! Is there no  sense of honor left in this country?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (practically) Well, haven't you got anybody else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nobody else on the paper who  can write! This'll break me, unless -- (he stares at Hildy;  then a light breaks) Hildy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to help me, Hildy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep away --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll bring us together again, Hildy --  just the way we used to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm afraid of. "Any time --  any place -- anywhere!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mock, Hildy, this is bigger  than anything that's happened to us.  Don't do it for me! Do it for the  paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away, Svengali.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you won't do it for love, how  about money? Forget the other offer  and I'll raise you twenty-five bucks  a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, you bumble-headed baboon --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- thirty-five, and not a  cent more!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please! Will you just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great grief! What's that other paper  going to give you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not working for any other paper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! In that case, the raise is off  and you go back to your old salary  and like it. Trying to blackjack --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this! (pulling her glove  off her left hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets glove off left hand and holds up an engagement r for him to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see this? Do you know what an  engagement ring is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at ring, swallows, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burns and Hildy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to tell you right away but  you started reminiscing. I'm getting  married, Walter, and also getting as  far away from the newspaper business  as I can get! I'm through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (himself again) Get married all you want to, Hildy,  but you can't quit the newspaper  business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't sell me that, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who says I can't? You're a newspaper  man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I'm quitting. I want to  go some place where I can be a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you, Hildy, and I know what  it would mean. It would kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) A journalist! Peeking through keyholes --  running after fire engines -- waking  people up in the middle of the night  to ask them if they think Hitler's  going to start a war -- stealing  pictures off old ladies of their  daughters that got chased by apemen!  I know all about reporters -- a lot  of daffy buttinskies going around  without a nickel in their pockets,  and for what? So a million hired  girls and motormen's wives will know  what's going on! No, Walter, I'm  through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you meet this man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bermuda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bermuda... Rich, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not what you'd call rich. Makes about  five thousand a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his line?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in the insurance business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up) The insurance business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the defensive) It's a good, honest business, isn't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sure, it's honest. But somehow, I  can't picture you with a guy who  sells policies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can, and I love it! He forgets  the office when he's with me. He  doesn't treat me like an errand-boy --  he treats me like a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does, does he? How did I treat  you -- like a water buffalo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about water buffaloes,  but I know about him. He's kind and  sweet and considerate. He wants a  home -- and children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, sounds more like a guy I ought  to marry. What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll give you a hint. By  tomorrow they'll be calling me Mrs.  Bruce Baldwin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow? Tomorrow... as quick as  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The quicker the better. Well -- I  finally got out what I came in to  tell you. (she extends her hand) So long, Walter, and better luck  next time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking her hand) I wish you everything I couldn't  give you, Hildy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad I couldn't see this guy first.  I'm pretty particular about whom my  wife marries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Well, he's waiting in the anteroom  for me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, could I meet him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, better not, Walter. Wouldn't do  any good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not afraid, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid? I should say not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right then, come on and let's  see this paragon. (gets hat) Is he as good as you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burns has his hat. They start toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what does he want with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Now you got me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing personal. I was just asking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the door, Burns walks ahead, opens door and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops as he realizes she's not there. The door opens.  Hildy comes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't believe this, Walter,  but Bruce holds the door open for  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) No kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reporters conversing. They stop as Hildy and Burns enter  scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Hildy follows Burns through the City Room. This time, contrast to Hildy's original walk through the room, the g are silent as they watch the two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to keep pace) And he takes his hat off when he's  with a lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder) What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) And when he walks with a lady, he  waits for her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops) Oh, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burns, at this point, has reached the switchboard. He say under his breath, to Maisie:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Have Duffy call me in the restaurant  in twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy, a little out of breath, catches up with him. At th iron gate that opens into anteroom Hildy jumps ahead, ope the gate and holds it for Burns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking right through) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy follows him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Hildy follows Burns in. Bruce is sitting on the bench. the end of a bench sits an old, grizzled Western Union "b Ignoring Bruce, Burns strides over to the "boy", seizes h hand, shakes it and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see right away my wife picked  out the right husband for herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy behind him. Bruce registers amazement at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The messenger is more amazed than Bruce as Burns keeps pu his hand vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be some mistake. I'm  already married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (you never saw a more  surprised man) Already married! (turning to Hildy  o.s.) Hildy, why didn't you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head at Burns' antics, but can't help smil nevertheless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again seizing  messenger's hand) Congratulations again, Mr. Baldwin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my name --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he enters scene) Mr. Burns!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burns turns slightly but doesn't release messenger's hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? You'll have to excuse me --  I'm busy with Mr. Bruce Baldwin here.  Just leave your card with the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce takes hold of Burns' coat and shakes it to get his  attention. Burns turns on him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry, but I'm busy! Look -- (he points o.s.) -- there's the boy. Take your card  and leave it with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away again. Bruce, determinedly, takes hold of h sleeve and pulls at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Burns --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wheeling around) I've just told you I was busy with  Mr. Bruce Baldwin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Bruce Baldwin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burns, still pumping the dazed messenger's hand, stops at this, drops hand, and turns to Bruce:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Bruce Baldwin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (accusing to messenger) Then who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (falteringly) My name's Pete Davis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete Davis! Well, Mr. Davis, this is  no concern of yours and after this  I'll thank you to keep out of my  affairs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The messenger isn't quite sure what he's done but he slin back to his seat as Burns turns to Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is beginning to get sore, but reluctantly again she i compelled to smile at Walter's behavior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaches for Bruce's  hand but grabs the  umbrella and begins  shaking the handle  up and down) This is a pleasure, Mr. Baldwin, and  I'm sorry about the mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he tries to shift  the umbrella, calling  Burns' attention to  it, and offers his  hand instead)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I thought there was something  funny... You see, Bruce, you don't  mind if I call you Bruce, do you?  After all, we're practically related --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (completely unnerved  by this time, and  you can't quite blame  him) Mr. -- well -- no -- no -- not at  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, my wife -- I mean, your  wife -- that is, I mean Hildy -- had  led me to expect that she was marrying  a much older man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (this is the final  crusher) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I see, she didn't mean old in  years. You always carry an umbrella,  Bruce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, er -- it looked a little cloudy  this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. -- Rubbers, too, I  hope? A man ought to be prepared for  any emergency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burns looks down. Bruce, in unconscious responses, helple lifts his foot up and we see the rubber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attaboy! (taking Bruce's arm  and leading him toward  elevator) Come on, Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going along, but  worried) Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going? I'm going to buy  you two lunch -- didn't Hildy tell  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a helpless look back  at Hildy) No -- she didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wanted to surprise you, I guess. (as the elevator is  about to pass, he  calls) Down! (practically shoving  Bruce in) After you, Bruce! (as Bruce disappears  inside he turns toward  Hildy) Come on, Hildy, my treat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't see the passengers. Hildy comes into scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose I can't call this off  without creating a scene -- but  remember, it's your last fling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurt) How do you like that? Here I am being  nice to you and your sweet-heart and  that's the thanks I get!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps into the elevator -- in a second he hops out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very sweetly -- he  almost sings it) Oh -- after you, Hildy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a look of disgust Hildy gets in. Burns follows and t door slams on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks after departed elevator and whistles. Then he gr all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me it's you, Hildy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK and discloses our three at a restaurant table. Nothing swanky -- a place like Jack Blake's in New York, say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beaming at waiter) Nobody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She extends her hand. The waiter takes it; they shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's everything, Gus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't complain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying menu) Well, I can. I'm hungry. Roast beef  sandwich -- rare. And some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I put a little rum in the  coffee? It's a nasty day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea. How about you, Hildy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (discarding menu) Oh -- I'll take the same, I guess.  And coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little rum in yours, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce looks at her. She hurriedly changes her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- just coffee, Gus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crestfallen) Just coffee. (to Bruce) And you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting menu down) Oh, I'll take the same, I guess. And  a glass of milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Milk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks he hasn't  heard) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head as  he writes it down) Milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't put any rum in it, Gus.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Gus gives him a look and goes.

dialogues.speaker: THE TRIO AT TABLE
dialogues.text: Burns surveys the others quizzically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a sigh) Well, so you're getting married  tomorrow, eh? How does it feel, Bruce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feels awful good. Yes, sir -- we're  taking the four o'clock train to  Albany and tomorrow we'll be married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (it's the Puritan in  him) Taking the train today -- and being  married tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whistles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising to the bait) Oh, it isn't like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reassuring Mrs. Grundy) It will be perfectly all right,  Walter. Mother is coming with us on  the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother? But your mother --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. My mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he gets it and  underlines it) Oh. Your mother -- well, of course,  that relieves my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bruce) Isn't it sweet of Walter -- still  wanting to protect me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives Burns that too-sweet look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apparently taking  this at face value) I know I wasn't a good husband, Hildy,  but you can always count on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little cookily) I don't think she'll need you very  much -- I aim to do most of the  protecting myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pats Hildy's arm -- she smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll tell you one thing, old  man, she never looked at me the way  she's looking at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might have, Walter, but you were  never there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I'm glad you two are going  to be happy and have all the things  I couldn't give her. You know, Hildy  is about the best reporter in the  country -- and that goes regardless  of sex. But all she really ever wanted  was a home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll try to give her one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you will, Bruce. Are you going  to live with your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for the first year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighing) That'll be nice. A home with mother.  A real honeymoon. In Albany, too.  Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That "ow" is sotto voce, but it's the direct result of a  kick under the table from Hildy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mighty nice little town, Albany.  They've got the State Capitol there,  you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know... (he chuckles) Hildy, will you ever forget the night  you brought the Governor back to  your hotel room and found me taking  a bath? She didn't even know I was  in town...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His laugh stops cold and he clutches for his shin again.  Hildy just looks. Providentially, the waiter enters the s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins serving them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to pick up  again after a second) How's business, Bruce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Albany's a mighty good insurance  town. Most people there take it out  pretty early in life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't blame them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus, who has just managed to come between Hildy and Burns lets out a startled "ouch".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry, Gus! My foot must  have slipped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pained expression  belies his words) That's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sometimes wish I'd taken out  insurance -- but, of course, now it  doesn't matter. Still, I suppose it  would have been the smart thing to  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I honestly feel that way. I  figure I'm in one line of business  that really helps people. Of course,  we don't help you much when you're  alive -- but afterward -- that's  what counts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fall to.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: She sips her coffee and acts surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus, this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winking) Good coffee, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: She smiles and winks back, and takes another sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus starts to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've forgotten my milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. The milk. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves scene, shaking his head. Burns sips his coffee. likes it. He lifts his cup to Hildy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's luck to the bride and  bridegroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lifts cup) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking for something  to respond with --  apologetically) He hasn't brought my milk yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus boy comes into scene and stops before Burns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want you on the phone, Mr. Burns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They would!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy goes, Burns rises, starts off, comes back for his cup coffee, which he then takes off with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking after him) You know, Hildy, he's not a bad  fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at him  maternally) You're so nice, Bruce, you think  everybody else is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he's not the man for you. I can  see that. But I sort of like him.  Got a lot of charm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes by it naturally. His  grandfather was a snake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) If anybody had told me I'd be sitting  at lunch with him -- but he swept me  right off my feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what he did to me. Swept me  right off my feet -- and left me  lying on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burns is listening, has coffee on ledge and sips it now a then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get this -- get Sweeney off that  yarn and out of town on a two weeks'  vacation -- and right away... All  right, Duffy, keep your shirt on.  Hildy's coming back... No. She doesn't  know it yet. But she'll be there. I  promise you, Duffy. And tell Louie  to stick around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up, smiles, and finishes the coffee. Then he gir himself for being crushed. He gradually begins to look su He pulls out a small mirror to study his expression till finally gets what he wants. He holds that expression as h comes out of the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus is entering the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your milk, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He serves Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I brought you another cup of  coffee, Hildy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus serves her and puts still another cup in front of Bur chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Gus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a sip and almost chokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too hot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gasping for breath) No. It's strong. (quickly) But I like it that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus goes, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking off) Say, what's happened to Burns? He  looks sunk, doesn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beaming) He certainly -- hic -- does!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burns comes into scene, looking like a 1929 banker just b jumping off a roof, and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just Sweeney again. One of my best  reporters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife had twins and he went out  to celebrate and got as drunk as a  lord. They can't even find him. (he sips his coffee) I tell you, drink is the ruin of  this nation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sipping hers) You said it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So -- Sweeney gets twins -- and Earl  Williams gets hanged tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what is the lowdown on Williams?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's simple. A poor little dope who  lost his job went berserk and shot a  cop who was coming after him to quiet  him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's nuts, why doesn't the State  just put him away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it happened to be a colored  policeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (for Bruce's benefit) The colored vote happens to be very  important to the Mayor of this town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially with an election coming  up in a few days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure Williams is not all  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you've got to do is talk to him.  But the Mayor would hang his own  grandmother to be re-elected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But couldn't you show the man wasn't  responsible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (there's a sly  expression on his  face) How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could run an interview that would  prove it. Remember the interview I  wrote with Jimmy Wellman? That saved  his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slapping hands  together) Yes, you could do it, Hildy. You  could save that poor devil's life.  You could -- but -- (the enthusiasm dies  away) -- you're going away. I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long would the interview take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- an hour for the interview.  Another hour to write it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could take the six o'clock train,  Hildy. If it would save a man's life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Bruce, dear. Don't you see? This  is a trick to get your sympathy. No,  Walter, I've been waiting for  something like this -- but I wasn't  sure when you'd spring it. If you  want to save Earl Williams' life,  you can interview him yourself. You're  still a good reporter. Bruce and I  will be on that four o'clock train --  and thanks just the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an editor. I know what ought to  be written, but I can't write it the  way you could. It needs a woman's  heart --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Walter, you're getting poetic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bruce) You see what I had to put up with?  She never trusted me! You argue with  her -- otherwise you're going on a  honeymoon with blood on your hands!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce gulps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you have any happiness after  that? All through the years you'll  remember that a man went to the  gallows because you were too selfish  to wait two hours! I tell you, Earl  Williams' face will come between you  on the train tonight -- and at the  preacher's tomorrow -- and all the  rest of your lives!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breaking into applause) What a performance! Bravo! Don't let  him fool you, Bruce -- it's only an  act!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, only an act? Haven't  you got any feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's either an act on your  part or a miracle on Sweeney's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I happen to know Sweeney was married  only three months ago. If he's got  twins this morning, I claim it was  done with mirrors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs, throws up  his hands) All right, Hildy, I'm licked. But  I'll make you and Bruce a business  proposition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bruce) Maybe you'll be. You're a smart young  man. You let Hildy do this story for  me and you can write out a $100,000.00  insurance policy for me. What do you  say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't use my wife for business  purposes, Mr. Burns!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, Bruce. What's  commission on a $100,000.00 policy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, at his age, twenty payment  life, a little over a thousand  dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's the matter with a thousand  dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to the budget, we laid out  that's more than our food bill for a  whole year. Listen, Bruce, I don't  want Walter Burns to use me, but I'm  perfectly willing to use him. How  long will it take to get him examined?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could get a company doctor in twenty  minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're talking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning on Burns) You keep out of this. Bruce, suppose  you examine Mr. Burns in his office.  I'll get my bag and go over to the  Press Room in the Criminal Courts  Building. You phone me as soon as  Mr. Burns has given you his check.  Then I'll go get the interview and  you phone Mother that we're taking  the six o'clock train. (back to Burns) And no tricks, Walter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What tricks would I pull?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing! Of course, you might  cancel the check. Yes! Wait a minute!  What would be his first payment on  that policy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About twenty-five hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better make that a certified check,  Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignantly) What do you think I am -- a crook?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes --- and that's putting it mildly!  No certified check -- no story --  Get me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. The check will be  certified. Want my fingerprints?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) No thanks, I've still got those.  Well, I'll step into some working  clothes and hop over to the Press  Room for the background on this yarn.  It'll be kind of fun to see the boys  again, too. Remember, Bruce, it must  be certified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, Bruce. Have you got  that money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling his pocket) The five hundred? Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On second thought, would you let me  have it? I'll get the tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, Bruce, I know what I'm  doing. He'd get you in a crap game --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't gamble, Hilda!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a lot of men who didn't do  anything till they met Walter Burns.  Please, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) All right. (he pulls out his  wallet) One -- two -- three -- four -- five.  Five hundred. Be careful, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be careful, darling. You be,  please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him, kisses her hand and pats it to Burns' che

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long, husbands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: leaving. She weaves just a bit.

dialogues.speaker: THE TWO MEN
dialogues.text: They look after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling a little) I never knew Hildy to be so determined  before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't seen anything yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce turns to look at Burns -- they look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT AT TELEPHONE
dialogues.text: It is ringing. A hand comes in to take the phone. CAMERA  DRAWS BACK A LITTLE to show Endicott taking the phone. He has an eye shade over his eyes and five cards in his othe hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Criminal Courts Press Room... This  is Endicott... No, nothing new on  the Williams case yet boss. Well,  you bet I'm here plugging away every  minute. (hangs up and studies  his cards) Up a dime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS SLOWLY to reveal the other players as they sp Playing are reporters Murphy, Endicott, Wilson, Schwartz McCue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dropping his cards) By me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also dropping) Droparoo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schwartz knocks on table and drops cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) I'll call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three sixes. Is that any good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sure looks good from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys all look up toward sound of Hildy's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: framed in the doorway. She is carrying a bag and has chan her costume to a tailored travelling suit. She grins and  comes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all talking at once as Hildy comes into the scen There are ad libs of "Hildy!" "Where'd you come from?" "H Mackeral, Hildy Johnson!", etc. Hildy raises her hand for silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One at a time, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She enters to a desk, places her bag on top of the desk,  takes her hat off and hangs it on a clothes tree in the  corner, comes back to desk and opens the travelling bag. through the above action she is talking rapidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not back for good. I'm just  covering the Earl Williams story for  Mr. Sweeney who had a sudden attack  of something but will be all right  by tomorrow. No, I haven't made up  with Walter Burns -- far from it! As  a matter of fact, I'm leaving tonight  for Albany and I'll be married  tomorrow morning. The lucky man is  Mr. Bruce Baldwin, a gentleman in  the insurance business -- and when I  say gentleman, I mean gentleman! Are  there any other questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy takes notebook and pencil out of bag, looks at the  stockings she is wearing, sees she has a run and takes a  fresh pair out of the bag. She sits down and begins to pu on the new stockings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Well, that about covers everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Now I want to ask you fellows  a couple of questions. Did Earl  Williams know what he was doing when  he fired that gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you ask us, no. If you ask the  state alienists, the answer is yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a simple story. Earl Williams  works for the E.J. McClosky  Manufacturing Company as a bookkeeper  for fourteen years. He starts in at  twenty dollars a week and gradually  works his way up to twenty-two fifty.  A year ago the McClosky Company goes  out of business and Williams loses  his job. (waving his hand toward  Wilson) Take it away, Fred Wilson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- Williams goes a little balmy  and begins making speeches on a plan  he's got to save the world. Only he  makes his speeches, usually, on a  very busy street and neglects to get  a license for it. Well, the cops let  him alone as much as they can because  he's harmless and they're kinda sorry  for him. But one day he decides to  hold a meeting right in the middle  of a Veteran's Parade and the cops  chase him. He gets scared and goes  into hiding. (gesturing toward  Schwartz) Come in, Dave Schwartz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His Honor, the Mayor, now comes out  with a statement that Earl Williams  is a dangerous character in the employ  of two or three foreign governments  and the police are going to get him  dead or alive. Somebody sends out a  tip that this guy is hiding in Molly  Malloy's joint. And this colored  policeman, Daniels, goes over to  pick Williams up. Williams has read  the papers, thinks the cop is going  to kill him and shoots first. That  is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, boys. That's all I want to  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy gets up, rolls the pair of stockings she has just  discarded into a ball, crosses to Bensinger's desk and pu the stockings in a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, that's old Prissy Bensinger's  desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I just want to give him a  thrill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy crosses back to desk and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, boys, now that everything  is settled, deal me in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy glances toward clock on wall. The hands show 2:45 P INSERT: CLOCK - Hands pointing to 2:45 PM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up phone nearest her on desk and starts to dial picking up cards dealt her with one hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello, this is Hildy Johnson. Get me  Walter Burns. (she studies her cards --  then, into phone) Hello, Walter. How's the old double- crosser?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telephone at his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, my fine-feathered friend.  Thought I might be hearing from you.  What have you got to report?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK TO MEDIUM SHOT and we see that Burns is stripped to the waist. A doctor is applying a stethoscope his chest. We HOLD the picture a second: Burns listening  intently on the phone and the doctor listening intently t his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Going all right, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor suddenly realizes what he's said and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting hand over  mouthpiece of phone) Doctor, will you please keep quiet a  minute? How do you expect me to get  any work done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Bruce, who has some papers i front of him at the desk. Bruce grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you expect me to get anywhere  if you're going to keep on that phone?  If you'll just give me two minutes  more --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Well, they haven't finished with me  yet but I'm hoping to get my shirt  back. Oh, no. I'm in the pink of  condition. They found two new dimples.

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE
dialogues.text: cards in her other hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about that check? All right, Mr.  Burns, but remember, no checkee --  no story. Well, as soon as they decide  whether you live or not will you  have that new man of mine call me  up? Yes, sir. (she hangs up) All right, boys. Up a dime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right back at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dropping his cards) You fight it cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And up a dime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying a second) I call. What you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (displaying her cards) Three bullets! Any good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing his cards  away) Beats king up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy rakes in the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do with all  that money, Hildy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- you can't spend it in Albany.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'll think of something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: taking in door and including group. Bensinger, another  reporter, comes in from the corridor. He stands out from others because of his tidy appearance, and carries a book under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Harvard! Got anything new on  the hanging?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cockily) Why don't you fellows get your own  news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you say 'hello' to a fellow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes over to shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, just a farewell appearance,  batting for Sweeney. I'm going into  business for myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting married tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, congratulations! Good luck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you use him for a  bridesmaid, Hildy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Hildy, your deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens a drawer, the one in which Hildy put her stockin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, who put these stockings in my  desk? (he turns to the group)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCUE's VOICE I don't know, but I think they got rats in building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (makes a gesture of  disgust and picks up  telephone) This is Bensinger. I just saw the  Sheriff. He won't move the hanging  up a minute... All right, I'll talk  to him again, but it's no use. The  execution is set for seven in the  morning. Get me a rewrite man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: dealing the cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't they hang that guy at a  reasonable hour, so we can get some  sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Jake, new lead on the hanging. This  new alienist from New York -- Dr.  Max J. Egelhoffer -- is going to  interview Williams in about half an  hour -- in the Sheriff's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy reaches for the phone. Without dropping his cards, jiggles the hook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must be the tenth alienist  they've had on Williams. Even if he  wasn't crazy before, he would be  after ten of those babies got through  psychoanalyzing him. (into phone) Gimme the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Egelhoffer's pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? What did he ever do for his  country?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you remember? He's the guy  went to Washington to interview the  Brain Trust, and gave out a statement  that they were all sane. It created  a sensation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is referring to his notes as he talks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Here's the situation on the eve of  the hanging:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues playing his cards:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) This is Murphy. More slop on the  hanging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) A double guard's been thrown around  the jail, municipal buildings,  railroad terminals, and elevated  stations to prepare for the expected  general uprising of radicals at the  hour of execution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Ready? The Sheriff's just put two  hundred more relatives on the payroll  to protect the city against the Red  Army -- which is leaving Moscow in a  couple of minutes. (consults his hand) Up a dime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) The Sheriff has just received four  more letters threatening his life,  but he says nothing can interfere  with his duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) And to prove to the voters that the  Red Menace is on the level, the  Sheriff has written himself four  more letters, threatening his life.  I know he wrote 'em on account of  the misspellings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trouble is, when the Red Menace shows  up the Sheriff will still be crying  'Wolf!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you got, Hildy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kings and sixes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing down) That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweeping coins in) 'Kings and sixes The pot affixes'...  Poetry. I learned that at my grandma's  knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I keep losing. My grandma  was a modest woman -- nobody ever  saw her knees, not even my grandpop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor has gone. Burns is adjusting his shirt. Bruce sitting at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. This makes me feel  funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why shouldn't I make Hildy my  beneficiary? I've got nobody else to  leave it to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel I ought to take care of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you'll take care of her. After  all, if that doctor's right, I'm  going to live for a long time yet.  Look, Bruce, this is a debt of honor.  I was a very bad husband: Hildy could  have got a lot of alimony if she'd  wanted to, but she wouldn't take  any. She had it coming to her, but  she was too independent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm independent, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figure it this way: I ought to be  good for twenty-five years. By that  time, you'll probably have made enough  so that the money won't mean anything.  But suppose you haven't made good --  don't you think Hildy's entitled to  a quiet old age without any worries?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, of course, if you put it that  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (everything he has on  the ball) And remember this, Bruce! I love  her, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm beginning to realize that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the beauty of it is she'll never  have to know 'till I've passed on.  Maybe she'll think kindly of me ---  after I'm gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a lump in his throat) Gee, you almost make me feel like a  heel -- coming between you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Bruce, you didn't come between  us. It was all over for her before  you came on the scene. For me --  it'll never be over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away, wipes his eyes, and sneaks a glance to see how that goes over. It goes over big -- Bruce hurriedly w a tear away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Duffy comes into the room. He advances toward the desk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (placing check on  desk) Here's that certified check, Walter. (sotto voce) I drew out my wife's savings, and if  this isn't back by 5:30 I'm a ruined  man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also sotto voce) Don't worry, Duffy, you'll have it  back by five. (louder) Thanks, Duffy. Stick around. (picking up check he  rises)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks over to Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Bruce, here you are -- certified  and everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also rising) Certified! I'm afraid Hildy'd feel  ashamed to think she hadn't trusted  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reacts to this sweetly solemn thought.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS AND BRUCE
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS THEM as Burns walks Bruce toward door, his arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she'll know some day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all I ask. Oh, wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He releases Bruce, runs back and gets umbrella and brings to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't want to forget this, you know.  Might start to rain again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. I'll phone Hildy right away  to get that story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are at the door. Burns opens the door for Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT FEATURING LOUIS
dialogues.text: Louis is sitting at a desk, apparently engrossed in a  newspaper. He is all alert, however. Bruce and Burns come into the scene talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, anyway, I know Hildy's getting  a good man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Thanks a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass Louis. He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE AND BURNS
dialogues.text: Bruce, still embarrassed, looks down. Burns turns and sig to Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burns points to Bruce's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I got to get back. You can  find your way out, can't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. (he extends his hand) Well, thanks for everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't thank me. I should thank you.  So long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and goes. Burns watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce is going out, his back toward Camera. Burns watches Louis comes between Burns and Bruce and follows Bruce out we see Bruce going toward outer door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rubs his hands in glee as he starts back for his offic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is raking in a pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why you boys are so  good to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing cards down) Your poker's improved a lot, Hildy.  Lend me two bucks, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing doing. I'm playing for keeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a whirr and crash from the gallows. They start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish they'd stop that practicing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others drift into the scene and look out of the windo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trap is sprung by two or three earnest men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns away) Well, anyhow, I won't be covering  stuff like this any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Getting yellow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A phone rings. McCue answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you, Hildy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy goes toward phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy Johnson... Oh, hello, Bruce.  Have you got it? Is it certified?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certified and everything. Got it  right here in my wallet... What? No,  he's not here -- I'm in a phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCue is hovering near.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certified, eh? Who is it -- your  milkman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in phone) But, Bruce, don't keep it in your  wallet!... Well, you see -- (she is thinking  rapidly) -- there's an old newspaper  superstition that the first big check  you get you -- you put in the lining  of your hat. That brings you good  luck for ten years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, I've been a reporter twenty  years and never heard any hooey like  that. Where'd you get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to McCue) I made it up just now, and who's  asking you? (into phone) I know it's silly, honey, but do it  for me, won't you?... Yes, right  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes check out of wallet, folds it into lining of hat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I've done it. Now, are  you satisfied?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. And here's a kiss for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She blows a kiss into the phone. Immediately we hear kiss sounds all over. She looks up and glares. Then back to ph

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, darling, you go back to the  hotel and pack and you and Mother  pick me up here about half-past five.  Goodbye, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He blows a kiss into the phone and hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Studying a paper, reads it for a moment. Bruce comes out restaurant and starts out. After a second, Louis follows  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden Cooley sits at a desk near the grilled doorway tha leads to the cells. He is studying a Racing Form. Hildy's hand reaches into the shot and flicks the newspaper. He l up. THE CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Hildy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Hildy! What are you doing  around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to interview Earl Williams,  Warden. How about a little service?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more interviews. Besides, a  doctor's coming over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy reaches down out of camera range -- comes up with b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, isn't this your twenty dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at bill eagerly) I think it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing it over) I thought so. Come on, I'm in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooley pockets the twenty and reaches for his key ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a milling mob around a center of activity that t Camera can't find.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF COP
dialogues.text: as he sees this and strolls determinedly toward it.

dialogues.speaker: THE CROWD
dialogues.text: The cop comes in and breaks ranks. He pushes his way towa center and looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lying down, held by Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy stole my watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lugging them both to  feet) Have you got his watch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's crazy. I haven't any watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw him. He put it in his back  pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't got --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop reaches into Bruce's back pocket. Watch comes out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Louis) Is this yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! That's it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never saw it before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cop grabs Bruce. Louis grabs his other arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whistles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to mob) Beat it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they go through crowd. The look on poor Bruce's face,  muddy anyhow, is something. Suddenly, Bruce cries:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My hat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get his hat, somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lying top up, in a puddle. Hand reaches in and picks it u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as hat is passed to cop, who jams it down on Bruce's head Another takem from Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at the door of Earl Williams' cell. Hildy sits on a stool the door, pencil and copy paper in hand. Earl Williams si at the edge of his cot, facing Hildy. There is a bouquet roses in a water pitcher by the cot. Our first impression Williams is that he's a rational, well-poised citizen. It only under Hildy's questioning that he gradually reveals  himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't plead insanity, because  you see I'm just as sane as anybody  else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled and worried) You didn't mean to kill that  policeman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not. I couldn't kill anybody --  it's against everything I've ever  stood for. They know it was an  accident. They're not hanging me for  that -- they're hanging me for my  beliefs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are your beliefs, Earl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're very simple. I believe in  the Golden Rule. I'm not the first  man to die for preaching it. But if  they would only listen to it -- we  could have a fine, decent world  instead of this mass of hate that  makes man do such cruel things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you go about applying the  Golden Rule, Earl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd do away with the profit system  and have production for use only.  There's enough food and clothing and  shelter for everybody if we'd use  some sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (writing) "Production for use only." Well,  maybe that's the answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the only answer. Everything has  a use and if we let it be used for  its purpose, we could solve all our  problems. Food was meant to be eaten,  not stored away in restaurants while  poor people starved; clothing was  meant to be worn, not piled up in  stores while people went naked.  Doesn't that make sense?
