dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) Yes, that makes a lot of sense, Earl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just use things for what they were  meant, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. (she studies him a  moment) What's the purpose of a gun, Earl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gun? (he thinks -- then a  revealing smile breaks  out) Why -- to shoot, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that how you came to shoot the  policeman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. You see, I'd never had a gun  in my hand before and I didn't know  what to do with it. Well, when I get  stuck, I know that there's an answer  for everything in production for  use. So it came to me in a flash:  what's a gun for? To shoot! So I  shot. Simple isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (writing) Very simple, Earl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing crazy about that, is  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Earl, not at all. (she indicates the  flowers) Who sent you the flowers, Earl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reverently) Miss Mollie Malloy. She's a wonderful  person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to picture  pinned on wall) Isn't that her picture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning toward it) Yes. Isn't she beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you should be pardoned, are you  figuring on marrying Mollie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, she's much too good for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Hartman has come into the scene. Hildy turns towa him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same way you did. (pointing) Through that gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave strict orders that nobody was  to interview Williams without my  permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then, I'll just run the  story that Sheriff Hartman is afraid  to let reporters interview his  prisoner. Of course, with election  coming, that might do you a lot of  harm, but just as you say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, wait a minute! I'm not afraid  of anything. What were you going to  write about Williams?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing much. Just that the state  had proved he was sane -- and he  admits it himself. If you don't want  me to run it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beaming) Oh, that'll be all right, Hildy. Go  ahead, run it. And you can say I  treated him well, too. (turning toward  Williams) 'Lo, Earl. How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, thanks, Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good, Earl. Oh, they've got  another alienist to see you. He ought  to be here any minute. Don't go to  sleep, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hildy) Hildy, how'd you like a couple of  tickets for the hanging?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low voice so  Williams won't  overhear) No, thanks Sheriff. I'm leaving town  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (just as loud as ever) You ought to stay over. You always  wrote a good hanging story, Hildy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's awful kind of you, Sheriff.  I've got to get started on my  interview. See you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget about production for  use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't, Earl. (she goes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game is on. Bensinger, at his desk, is reading a book The electric lights have been switched on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raking in a pot) Well, a guy can win when Hildy ain't  around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this guy she's gonna marry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baldwin -- his name is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I give that marriage six months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy won't be able to stay away  from a paper any longer than that.  Did you see her eyes light up when  she came in here? Like an old fire  horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says she's gonna write fiction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if she's gonna write fiction,  there's nothing like being a reporter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give ten to five that marriage  won't last six months. Hildy's a  newspaper man. She's got headlines  in her veins -- the way we all have  or we'd be out of these lousy jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mollie Malloy appears in doorway. She moves slowly into t room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well -- Miss Mollie Malloy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mollie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's tricks, Mollie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been lookin' for you tramps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid, those were pretty roses you  sent Earl. What do you want done  with them tomorrow morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tensely) A lot of wise guys, ain't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortably) You're breaking up the game, Mollie.  What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to tell you what I think of  you -- all of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy appears in the doorway and comes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your shirt on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Murphy) If you was worth breaking my fingers  on, I'd tear your face wide open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy goes to desk and begins typing away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you sore about, sweetheart?  Wasn't that a swell story we gave  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You crumbs have been making a fool  out of me long enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising and coming  over) She oughtn't be allowed in here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flaring) I never said I loved Earl Williams  and was willing to marry him on the  gallows! You made that up! And about  my being his soul-mate and having a  love-nest with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been sucking around that cuckoo  ever since he's been in the death- house. Everybody knows you're his  sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She blows up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lie! I met Mr. Williams  just once in my life when he was  wandering around in the rain without  his hat and coat on, like a sick  dog, the day before the shooting. I  went up to him like any human being  would and I asked him what was the  matter, and he told me about being  fired after working at the same place  for fourteen years, and I brought  him up to my room because it was  warm there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is typing away, stops to look over at Mollie, then  resolutely turns away, studies her stuff, and begins typi again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, put it on a phonograph!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because you want to fill your  lying paper with a lot of dirty  scandal, you got to crucify him and  make a stooge out of me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mollie) Got a match?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heedless) I tell you he just sat there talking  to me -- all night. And never once  laid a hand on me. In the morning he  went away, and I never saw him again  till that day at the trial!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lashes out at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, laugh! I'd like to know some  curses bad enough for your greasy  souls! Sure, I was his witness --  the only one he had. Yes -- me --  cheap little Mollie Malloy! I'm  everything the District Attorney  said I was. And still I was the only  one with guts enough to stand up for  him! I told the truth and the District  Attorney knows it! That's why you're  persecutin' me! Because Earl Williams  treated me decent and not like an  animal -- and I said so!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally irritated) Go into your dance! This is the Press  Room. We're busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you go and see your boy- friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winks at the others) But you'll have to hurry up -- he  left a call for seven A.M.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through her teeth) It's a wonder a bolt of lightning  don't come down and strike you all  dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From o.s. comes sound of the gallows. Mollie gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly uncomfortable) Don't get hysterical, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (begins to sob) Shame on you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hysterically) A poor little fellow that never meant  nobody no harm! Sitting there alone  this minute with the Angel of Death  beside him, and you cracking jokes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: typing away furiously, regardless of this. She ends a pag The sound of Mollie sobbing comes over the scene. Hildy  inserts a fresh page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't shut up, we'll give you  something to cry about!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy looks o.s. and rises determinedly.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLIE BACKING AWAY FROM MURPHY
dialogues.text: She is still sobbing. Hildy comes into scene and puts her arm around Mollie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Come on, Mollie. This is no place  for you. (she leads Mollie  toward door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not human!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're newspaper men, Mollie. They  can't help themselves. The Lord made  them that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (one look back as  Hildy leads her out  door) It wasn't the Lord! It was the devil!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy and Mollie exit. There is a pause. The boys look at each other uncomfortably. The phone rings. Wilson goes to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up cards) You guys wanna play some more poker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the use? I can't win a pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Who? Hildy Johnson? She just stepped  out. She'll be back in a second.  Who? Oh, Mr. Baldwin. Well, if you'll  hang on a minute, she ought to be  right in. All right. (he covers transmitter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to others) Baldwin. The blushing bridegroom --  himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wants Hildy -- and sounds very  excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy comes back. Looks at them and stares contemptuously

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen of the Press! Always picking  on somebody who can't defend himself --  the littler the better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone for you, Hildy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going toward it) Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, some insurance man. Are you in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing phone) Give me that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello! Hello! Bruce?... what?...  Where are you?... You're where?...  How did that happen?... (she listens  unbelievingly a second) I'll be right over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Hildy hangs up and darts out of room. The others watch amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, did you see her go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lioness Rushes to Defense of Cub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you Baldwin was in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably went out without his hankie  and wants Mamma to wipe his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still give that marriage six months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, baby, get me the Sheriff's  offico, will you... Hello, Sheriff  Hartman?... This is Bensinger. How  about that favor? You know what:  once and for all, will you hang this  guy at five A.M. instead of seven?  It won't hurt you and we can make  the City Edition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignantly) Once and for all, I'm not going to  hang anybody except at the legal  hour... What? Don't threaten me,  Bensinger! I'm not afraid of any  newspapers. Yeah?... Oh, shut up! (he hangs up; an  afterthought -- he  calls up operator) And, operator, I told you not to  disturb me! I don't care who calls --  I don't want to be disturbed again  till I tell you! (he hangs up -- turns  to somebody o.s. and  speaks) How do you like that, Dr. Egelhoffer?  Want me to hang williams at their  convenience!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK TO A MED. GROUP SHOT, showing Williams, Sheriff Hartman and Dr. Egelhoffer. They are the only  occupants of room. Williams is seated facing a large stan searchlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The newspapers! Sheriff, they're the  scum of modern civilization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're always after me for  interviews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fencing) Of course, I sort of promised them I  would give out a statement when I  got through here. You don't mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not liking it) Well, I don't know if that's ethical.  You see, all statements are supposed  to come from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he'll bargain) We'll have to satisfy them. What  would you say to giving them a joint  interview? I could give them some of  the psychological aspects of the  case and you could give them the  legal aspects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he buys) A joint interview, eh? That might be  all right. We could have our pictures  taken together, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, shaking hands. I don't take a  very good picture, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. The publicity's  the main thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I suppose so. It all helps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (just a spectator up  to now) Are you gentlemen all through with  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry. I forgot you were  here. No, Mr. Williams, we still  have some questions for you. Sheriff,  will you kindly extinguish the lights?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff puts out the lights and the Doctor switches o the searchlight, which shines in Williams' face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know you are to be executed, Mr.  Williams. Who do you feel is  responsible for that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The system. But I'm not afraid to  die, Doctor. I'm dying for what I  believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. You realize, however, that  you committed a crime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a legal sense, yes. But not  actually. Actually, I'm innocent. I  didn't do anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm innocent. I didn't do anything.  I never stole a watch in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to show us Bruce in police cell. Hildy  outside. A police lieutenant with her in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you didn't, Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She whirls on lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to lieutenant) Let him out of here, Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conciliatingly) But, Hildy, I can't. He's accused of  stealing a watch. And they found the  watch on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who accused him? Diamond Louis!  One of the worst crooks in town! Why  don't you arrest Louis instead of  innocent people that he frames?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Hildy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't Hildy me! Are you going to let  him out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. You can't. But tomorrow  the Post will run the story of that  roulette game on 43rd Street that  your brother-in-law runs. And we'll  print that you get five hundred a  month for forgetting about it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Hildy, don't be hasty! I can't  let him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can let him out on bail, can't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll take fifty and like it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wavers) Well, all right. But I'm liable to  get into a jam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to open cell door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll get into a worse one if you  don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy is combing Bruce's hair. He begins to look presenta He fumbles in his breast pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost my wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops) The check, Bruce!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce picks up his hat and gets check out of lining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right here. Gee, it was lucky  your telling me about that old  newspaper superstition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking check and  putting it away) Yes, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't imagine who did it. I can't  think of any enemies I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at him fondly) I'm sure you haven't any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a minute, I thought maybe Walter  Burns was at the back of it. But  then I realized he couldn't have  been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. How could you ever think of  such a thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I realized right away. He's really  a very nice fellow, Hildy -- I found  that out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he is... Look, Bruce, we're  taking that next train -- and when I  say next train, this time I mean it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you finish the interview?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to driver) The Criminal Courts Building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bruce) No -- but I'm sure it'll be all right  with Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, gee, Hildy -- he gave us that  insurance business -- and you promised --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the story's practically  finished. I'll just go upstairs and  send it over with a messenger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab stops. Hildy gets out and Bruce starts to follow. Hildy turns and pushes him back in the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at door of cab. Bruce in cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you stay here. I'm not taking  any more chances. I'll be down in  three minutes -- and don't you dare  move!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy turns and starts for stairs of Criminal Courts Buil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schwartz is reading Hildy's interview to the other boys, are grouped around. Bensinger is at his desk, a book open but listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "But the State has a production for  use plan, too. It has a gallows and  at seven A.M., unless a miracle  occurs, that gallows will be used to  separate the soul of Earl Williams  from his body. And out of Molly  Malloy's life will go the one kindly  soul she ever knew --" (he stops) That's as far as Hildy got. But, I  ask you, can that girl write an  interview?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it's very ethical  reading other people's stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give us that ethics stuff.  You'll be the only one who'll swipe  any of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still say anybody that writes like  that ain't going to give it up  permanently to sew sox for a guy in  the insurance business. Now I give  that marriage three months and I'm  laying three to one. Any takers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take that bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn. Hildy comes into the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going to her phone) It's getting so a girl can't step  out of the room without being  discussed by a bunch of old ladies. (into phone; her voice  assumes a silken  quality) Hello, Post... Mr. Walter Burns,  please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Well, Hildy, we were only saying  that a swell reporter like you  wouldn't give this up so easily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) This is Hildy Johnson... (to Schwartz) Oh, I can give it up all right.  Without a single quiver. I'm going  to live like a human being -- not  like you rats. (into phone) Oh, is that you, Walter dear? Oh, I  didn't mean "dear." That was just  habit, I guess. Oh, be yourself,  Walter. I've got some news for you...  Yes, I got the interview, but I've  got some news that's more important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others are listening, suspecting a scoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better get a pencil out and write it  down. All ready? (then with a sudden  change of pace) Get this, you double-crossing  chimpanzee, there ain't gonna be any  interview and there ain't gonna be  any story... Huh? That certified  check of yours is leaving with me in  twenty minutes. And if I ever see  you again, it's going to be just too  bad... Eh?... Oh, you don't know  what I'm angry about, do you? If you  come over I'll be very glad to tell  you the story of Louie's watch. I  dare you to come over, you -- you --  skunk in sheep's clothing! And bring  that bodyguard of yours, too -- you'll  need him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And I just want you to listen to  one more thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets her story out of typewriter, applies it to  transmitter and tears it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear that? That's the interview I  wrote... Yes, I know we made a  bargain. I just said I'd write it --  I didn't say I wouldn't tear it up.  Yes, it's all in little pieces now,  Walter, and I hope to do the same  for you some time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches under her desk, pulls up bag, talking all the time. The others are too startled to do anything but list

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's my farewell to the  newspaper game. I'm going to live a  normal life and have a home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches into the drawer of desk and gets some stuff w she puts into bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to be a woman, not a  newsgetting machine. I'm going to  have babies and nurse them and love  them and give 'em cod liver oil and  worry about their new teeth -- and  the minute I catch one of them even  looking at a newspaper, I'm going to  brain him! Where's my hat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone points to her hat. She rises and goes toward it. bag is still open. Her phone rings. Schwartz answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (subdued tones) Hello, Mr. Burns. Yes, she's still  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping midway to  her hat) I'll take it. (she comes over to  phone) What's the matter, Mr. Burns -- don't  you understand English? -- Why, your  language is shocking, Mr. Burns --  positively shocking! I don't mind  because I was married to you and  know what to expect, but suppose  Central is listening in... Oh, did  you hear that, Central? We ought to  report him, don't you think?... Oh,  fooey on you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls the phone out of the wall, walks toward window tosses it out of the window. She waits for the crash, tur back and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now where was that hat? Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts toward it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you're pretty nearly through  with me, Doctor, I'm getting a little  fatigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you don't want to tire him  out, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one thing more. I'd like to  reenact the crime, Mr. Williams. May  I have your gun, please, Sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hartman starts to take gun out, hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insistently) Come, come, Sheriff, lightning doesn't  strike in the same place twice.  Nothing's going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hartman hands him the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, the Sheriff will be Mollie  Malloy, in whose room you were. You  will be Earl Williams. And I will be  the policeman. Follow me, Mr.  Williams?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Egelhoffer hands the gun to Williams and then backs up a paces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So -- now I say to you: 'Earl  Williams, you are under arrest!' and  you point your gun at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) Well, it wasn't exactly that way --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insistently) Point the gun at me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Williams does so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Williams hesitates for a moment and then pulls the trigge Hartman promptly dives under the desk as Egelhoffer toppl over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pathetically) Now can I go, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a loud banging on the door and a voice calling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Sheriff! Open up! What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Williams, alarmed by voice, turns and starts toward windo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy is now wearing her hat and gloves. She picks up her bag and starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Yonson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long, Hildy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send us a postcard, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'll keep the lamp in the window  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Hildy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy has crossed to doorway, the CAMERA TRUCKING WITH HE She turns and faces the room to make a last bravura speec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, goodbye, you wage-slaves. When  you're crawling up fire escapes,  getting kicked out of front doors,  and eating Christmas dinners in one- armed joints, don't forget your pal,  Hildy Johnson! And, remember, my  husband sells insurance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and starts on a bit of verse:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "It takes a heap o' livin' to make a  house a home."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is interrupted by a terrific fusillade of shots in th courtyard. A roar of excited voices comes up. For a tense second, everyone is motionless. There is another volley o shots. Wilson, Endicott and Murphy jump for the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the riot guns! Spread out, you  fellows! Etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a jail-break!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at window,  simultaneously) Cooley! What's the matter What's  happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch the gate! He's probably trying  the gate!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, a siren begins to wail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out the window) Who got away? Who was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earl... Williams!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Who'd he say? Earl Williams! It  was Earl Williams! He got away! Etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy ---! Gimme that telephone! (works hook frantically) Hurry! Hurry up! This is important!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Searchlights hit the windows, sweeping from direction of jail. Hildy stands paralyzed, her bundle in her hand. The is another rifle volley. Two windowpanes crash into the r Some plaster falls. Gongs sound above the siren. The boys are jumping for their telephones. Another windowpane goes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) Look out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out the window) Look out where you're aiming, will  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of reporters at their various phones follows: "Gimme the  desk!" "Flash!" "Earl Williams just escaped!" "Don't know yet -- call you back.", etc., are shouted into the phones Schwartz, Wilson, McCue, Endicott, Bensinger and Murphy.  After each man communicates with his paper, he dashes for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last of the reporters is gone.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: Her bag, almost unnoticed, falls to the floor. CAMERA TRU WITH HER as she moves back into the room, absently grabbi and trailing a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lets go of the chair and takes one of the telephones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning Post?... Get me Walter Burns --  quick! Hildy Johnson calling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very calmly she sits on the long table, her back against wall and waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter?... Hildy. Earl Williams just  escaped from the County Jail. Yep...  yep... yep... don't worry! I'm on  the job!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is another volley outside. Hildy sails her hat and  starts peeling off her gloves as she jumps for the door.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE GATE
dialogues.text: There are the reporters joining armed guards who are leap into squad cars ready for the chase. Cooley is beside the gate. As the reporters and guards pile into the cars, the gate opens and out they go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy comes on a run from this door, hesitates a moment,  then sees something o.s. and runs for it.

dialogues.speaker: SQUAD CAR
dialogues.text: as it comes careening across courtyard toward gate. Hildy tears into scene, jumps for and makes the running-board, hangs there as the car swerves up to the gate.

dialogues.speaker: AT GATE
dialogues.text: Hildy notices Cooley as the car, gathering speed, goes by him. She leaps from the running-board and lands clump on  Cooley.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY AND COOLEY
dialogues.text: Cooley has been knocked to the ground by the impact of Hi leap. She is sitting on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooley, I want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to get up) Hildy -- I can't. I'm busy -- I --  Let me up, Hildy. Earl Williams has  escaped --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He struggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's money in it, Cooley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't Hildy. It means my job! It  means --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting him) A lot of money. (she opens her bag) Four hundred and fifty dollars --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She fingers the bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four hundred and fifty dollars. Is  it a deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a deal. Let me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooley gets up and dusts himself off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (money still in her  hand) First we talk. How did Earl Williams  get that gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooley looks around quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, and I'll tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jerks his head, indicating to Hildy to follow him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move off as the gates are closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is empty. All the telephones are ringing crazily Endicott enters hurriedly, crosses to his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Endicott talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) No -- nobody knows where he got the  gun, but I think Mollie Malloy  smuggled it in to him. He ran up the  fire-escape, and went back in the  infirmary window. Then he got out  through the skylight. He must have  slid down the rain-pipe to the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme the Desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: including Murphy and Endicott at separate phones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I tell you! Nobody knows where  he got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Crime Commission has offered a  reward of ten thousand dollars for  Williams' capture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up swiftly and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No clue yet as to Earl Williams'  whereabouts. Here's a little feature  though: There's been an accident  about a tear bomb --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson enters and picks up his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Wilson talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- tear bomb. Criminals cry for  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: including Murphy, Wilson and doorway. The Sheriff enters, turning as he enters. As he turns back to someone in corr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the Mayor wants me, he knows where  I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) This tear bomb went off unexpectedly  in the hands of Sheriff Hartman's  Bombing Squad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What went off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Four of Mr. Hartman's Deputy Sheriffs  were rushed to the hospital --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fine fair-weather friend you are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (remorselessly, into  phone) The names are Merwyn D. Mayor, who  is the Mayor's brother-in-law --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all I've done for you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Howard Shenken, the Sheriff's uncle  on his mother's side --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello, Jim? Sidelights on Sheriff  Hartman's manhunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff spins around -- another enemy. At this moment Hildy enters the room and crosses casually to her telepho where she stands waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) William Lungren, who is the Sheriff's  landlord, and Lester Bartow who  married the Sheriff's niece. You  remember, the very homely dame. Call  you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Mrs. William Tausig, age fifty-five,  scrub lady, while at work scrubbing  the eighth floor of the Commerce  Building, was shot in the left leg  by one of Sheriff Hartman's deputies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hartman groans. There is a sound of machine-gun firing in the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There goes another scrub lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) I'll go right after it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hildy) Any dope yet on how he got out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From all I can get the Sheriff let  him out so's he could vote for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very disappointed in you, Hildy  Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: taking in Hildy and Murphy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you suppose Williams got that  gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Hildy shrugs, there is another flurry of machine-gun f Murphy leaves precipitately. Hildy, alone at last, picks the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Give me Walter Burns -- quick --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lays down the telephone receiver and crosses to the d which she closes, then returns to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up phone) Walter, listen. I've got the inside  story on how Williams got the gun  and escaped.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: at his desk, telephone to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exclusive? That's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It cost me four hundred and fifty  bucks to tear it out of Cooley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind that. What's the story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind it? That's not my money!  That's Bruce's money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll get it. Now what's the story? (he raises his hand) I'll have the paper send the money  right down to you. I swear it on my  mother's grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Your mother's alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant on my grandmother's grave.  Don't be so technical, Hildy. What's  the story?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this expert Dr. Egelhoffer,  from New York, decides to make  Williams re-enact the crime --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to giggle at the thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm coming to it. It seems the  Professor had to have a gun to re- enact the crime with -- and who do  you suppose supplied it? Nobody else  but that great thinker, Sheriff  Hartman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) No kidding, Hildy. (suspiciously) Say, this isn't a rib?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is on the level, Walter.  I'm not good enough to make this one  up. The Sheriff gave his gun to the  Professor, the Professor gave it to  Earl, and Earl gave it right back to  the Professor -- right in the stomach!  Who? No, Egelhoffer wasn't hurt badly.  They took him to the County Hospital  where they're afraid he'll recover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great work, Hildy... Huh? Oh,  will you stop worrying about the  money? I'll see you get it in fifteen  minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It better be fifteen minutes, because  Bruce is waiting downstairs in a  taxicab and that meter's clicking  away to beat the band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK disclosing Louis and a blonde sitting o divan in Walter's office. Burns' beckons the blonde:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his hand carefully  over receiver of  phone) Come here. There's a guy waiting in  a taxi in front of the Criminal Courts  building. His name is Bruce Baldwin.  Can you do your stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never flopped on you, have I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then scram! You've got about two  minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Sorry to keep you waiting. How much  was it again? Four hundred and fifty  dollars? Hang on a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his hand over the phone again and beckons to Loui

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Louis) I need four hundred and fifty dollars  in counterfeit money. You know where  I can get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's awful funny -- I happen to have  some on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) It's coming right over. I'm sending  it over with Louis. Thanks for the  story and good luck on your honeymoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep the thanks, but just see that  the money gets here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up. The door opens and McCue enters and crosses his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Hildy. I thought you were  gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought so, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy takes a look at the clock, rises and begins to pace and down, pounding her hands together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) McCue speaking. Mrs. Phoebe DeWolfe,  eight-sixty-one and a half South  State Street, colored, gave birth to  a pickaninny in a patrol wagon with  Sheriff Hartman's special Rifle Squad  acting as nurses. Well -- Phoebe was  walking along the street when all of  a sudden she began -- that's right.  So the police coaxed her into the  patrol wagon and they started a race  with the stork. When the pickaninny  was born the Rifle Squad examined  him carefully to see if it was Earl  Williams who they knew was hiding  somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy is still pacing. McCue laughs at his own joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hildy) Did you get that, Hildy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy's phone rings. She answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello -- Bruce! I thought you were  downstairs in a -- What? Arrested  again! What for this time, Bruce?  Mashing! Oh, Bruce, can't I leave  you alone for three minutes even?  Well, where are you? The 27th  Precinct? All right, I'll be right  over -- (she breaks off and  looks down at her  bag on the desk) I'll be over in twenty minutes, Bruce. (she hangs up) If I ever see Walter Burns -- (she picks up phone  and dials viciously) Get me Walter Burns... Hildy Johnson!  Well, he was there just a minute  ago! Have him call me back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to McCue) If Walter Burns calls, hold the wire  for me, will you? I'll be right back. (she goes out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Hildy. (into phone) Well, we can't get any official  statement --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and the Mayor enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Oh, wait a minute -- here's the Mayor.  Maybe he'll give us one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: turning away with a wave of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't pester me now, please. I got a  lot on my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) His Honor won't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up and exits out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCue comes in to him. Murphy and Endicott come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to McCue) Have you seen Sheriff Hartman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to say, Your Honor. The  place is so full of cockroaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Your Honor, what effect's this  jail-break going to have on the  colored voters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not an iota. In what way can an  unavoidable misfortune of this sort  influence the duty of every citizen,  colored or otherwise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, is there a Red Menace or  ain't there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff comes scooting in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Sheriff) Hartman, I've been looking for you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes in on the Sheriff, followed by the reporters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So have we!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the dope, Sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who engineered this getaway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute! We've got him located.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Williams?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where he used to live. You can catch  the Riot Squad -- it's just going  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys beat it, fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete, I want to talk to you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't got time, Fred, honest. I'll  see you after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you actually give Williams that  gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a wail) The professor asked me for it -- I  thought it was for something  scientific!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete, I've got a mighty unpleasant  task to perf --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff suddenly nudges him for quiet, and the Mayor, turning, sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: coming in and going to the phone. He is whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Your Honor. (into phone) Schwartz calling. (to the Mayor) How about it, Your Honor? Any  statement on the Red uprising  tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Red uprising?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There'll be no Red uprising!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Gimme rewrite -- (to the Mayor) The Governor says the situation calls  for the militia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can quote me as saying that  anything the Governor says is a tissue  of lies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello, Jake. Here's a red-hot  statement from the Governor. He claims  that the Mayor and the Sheriff have  shown themselves to be a couple of  eight-year-olds playing with fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quote him as follows: "It is a lucky  thing for the city that next Tuesday  is Election Day, as the citizens  will thus be saved the expense of  impeaching the Mayor and the Sheriff."  That's all -- call you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up and starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to have seen you, Mayor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits, whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to go somewhere private,  Pete. I've got to talk to you straight  from the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they start for the door it opens. As they exit Hildy  enters, almost crossing them but not quite noticing them she starts pounding her hands together and pacing up and  down Press Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they start down the hall, CAMERA TRUCKING WITH THEM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beside himself) Now, listen, Fred. Just give me a  few hours before you make any  decisions. I'll get results. I'm  doing everything humanly possible.  I've just sworn in four hundred  deputies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four hundred! Do you want to bankrupt  this administration?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleadingly) I'm getting them for twelve dollars  a night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve dollars! -- For those rheumatic  uncles of yours? (gesturing) Out shooting everybody they see for  the fun of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with dignity) If you're talking about my brother- in-law, he's worked for the city  fifteen years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come to the door of the Sheriff's office. Hartman op door and the Mayor enters, Hartman following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hartman closes door and turns to Mayor, who faces him  portentously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete, you're through!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned) What do you mean -- through?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean I'm scratching your name off  the ticket Tuesday and running  Czernecki in your place. It's nothing  personal. And, Pete -- it's the only  way out. It's a sacrifice we all  ought to be glad to make.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (David to Jonathan) Fred!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Pete! Please don't appeal to my  Sentimental side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred, I don't know what to say. A  thing like this almost destroys a  man's faith in human nature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you wouldn't talk like that,  Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our families, Fred. I've always looked  on Bessie as my own sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wavering and desperate) If there was any way out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a phone rings:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a way out. I've got Williams  surrounded, haven't I? What more do  you want? (into phone) Hello... Yes... Hello! (wildly) Four hundred suppers! Nothing doing!  This is a man-hunt -- not a  banquet!... The twelve dollars  includes everything!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That gives you an idea of what I'm  up against!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hotly) We're up against a lot more than  that with that nutty slogan you  invented: 'Reform the Reds With a  Rope'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Williams ain't a Red, and you know  it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's a lot of Communistic  sympathizers around --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it! But they've got nothing  to do with this case! Do you realize  there are two hundred thousand votes  at stake and unless we hang Earl  Williams we're going to lose 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we're going to hang him, Fred.  He can't get away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean he can't get away?!  He got away, didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knocking louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's out there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Sheriff Hartman in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff starts for door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved) Ah! For me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff opens the door. A small, very colorless and  ineffectual man named Pinkus is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he opens door,  disclosing Pinkus) I'm Sheriff Hartman. You want me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming in) You're certainly a hard fellow to  find, Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a document  from his pocket and  proffering it to  Sheriff) I'm a messenger at the State House.  This is from the Governor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's from the Governor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reprieve for Earl Williams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned) For who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amiably) Earl Williams. The reprieve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W-wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting his bearings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bursting forth) The Governor gave me his word of  honor he wouldn't interfere. Two  days ago!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you fell for it, Pete. It  frightens me what I'd like to do to  you. (to Pinkus) Who else knows about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff, with shaking hands, opens and begins to read the thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were all standing around when  he wrote it. It was after they got  back from fishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sheriff) Get the Governor on the phone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helpfully) You can't get him on the phone. He's  out duckshooting now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fishing! Duckshooting! How do you  like that. A guy does nothing more  strenuous for forty years than play  pinochle -- he gets elected Governor  and right away he thinks he's Tarzan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrusting the document  at the Mayor) Read it! Insane, he says. (shaking a finger in  Pinkus' face) He knows very well that Williams  ain't insane!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Pure politics!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An attempt to ruin us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. Hartman starts for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) Dementia praecox Oh-h-h!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got to think fast before those  lying reporters get hold of this.  What'll we tell 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell 'em the party is through in  this State on account of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Fred -- (into phone) Hello... this is Hartman --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apoplectic) And you can tell 'em as an  afterthought that I want your  resignation now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the phone) Sssh. Wait, Fred. (excitedly, into phone) What?... Where?... Where? Holy Moses!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got him! (back to phone) Wait a minute -- hold the wire. (to the Mayor) They got Earl Williams surrounded --  the Riot Squad has -- in his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell 'em to hold the wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. (into phone) Hold the wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cover up that transmitter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff does so. Mayor faces Cooney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, listen! You never arrived here  with this -- reprieve. Get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blinking) Yes, I did, just now. Don't you  remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much do you make a week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) How much do you make a week? What's  your salary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) Forty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) No -- don't out me off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you like to have a job for  three hundred and fifty dollars a  month. That's almost a hundred dollars  a week!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Who do you think!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinkus is a little startled; the Mayor hastens to adopt a milder manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, listen. There's a fine opening  for a fellow like you in the City  Sealer's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The City Sealer's office!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean here in the city?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (foaming) Yes, yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at phone) Well, wait a minute, will you? I'm  in conference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a very deliberate  intellect) No, I couldn't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't work in the city. You  see, I've got my family in the  country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperate) But you could bring 'em in here!  We'll pay all your expenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with vast thought) No, I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For heaven's sake, why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got two kids going to school there,  and if I changed them from one town  to another, they'd lose a grade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they wouldn't -- they'd gain  one! And I guarantee that they'll  graduate with highest honors!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lured) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hold your horses -- will you, Olsen?  Hurry up, Fred!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This puts me in a peculiar hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it doesn't. (hands him the reprieve) Now, remember: you never delivered  this. (rushing him to the  door) You got caught in the traffic, or  something. (opening door) Now, get out of here and don't let  anybody see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how do I know...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in and see me in my office  tomorrow. What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinkus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking out his wallet) All right, Mr. Pinkus, all you've  got to do is lay low and keep your  mouth shut. Here! (he hands him a card) Go to this address. It's a nice,  homey little place, and they'll take  care of you for the night. Just tell  'em Fred sent you. And here's fifty  dollars on account.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes money into Pinkus's hand and pushes him through the door. Pinkus goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone,  desperately) Will you wait, Olsen? I'll tell you  in a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens again and Pinkus comes back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forgot to tell me what a City  Sealer has to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning hastily toward  Pinkus) I'll explain it tomorrow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it hard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! It's easy -- it's very easy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleadingly, into  phone) Just one second --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good, because my health ain't  what it used to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing him out the  door) We'll fix that, too. (he closes the door  after him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone -- one  more plea) Just -- one -- second!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to the Mayor with a gesture of appeal. The Mayor closes the door and turns to Hartman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (huskily) All right. Tell 'em to shoot to kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot to kill, I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Fred. There's that  reprieve if they ever find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody reprieved that policeman he  murdered. Now, do as I tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello, Olsen... Listen... (his voice is weak) Shoot to kill... That's the orders  pass the word along... No! We dont  want him! And listen, Olsen, five- hundred bucks for the guy that does  the job... Yes, I'll be right out  there. (hangs up) Well, I hope that's the right thing  to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now take that guilty look off your  face, Pete -- and stop trembling  like a horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mopping his brow) If we didn't have election Tuesday  I'd have this on my conscience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louie comes from the direction of the stairs and crosses  toward door to Press Room. He pauses a moment, puts his h in his pocket, pulls out some bills, counts them and open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy is still pacing, pounding her hands together and  glancing every so often at the clock on the wall. Suddenl she crosses to her phone, picks up transmitter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Will you try --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wheeling towards  door) Louie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drops the phone and hurries towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got my dough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. The boss sent me over with  it. Four hundred dollars, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four hundred and fifty and I'll cut  your throat if you try any tricks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right. You can't blame  a guy for tryin', can you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on with that money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First you got to sign a receipt. (he pulls out a receipt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your shirt on. I got it -- right  here. (he picks out money  and counts) One hundred -- two hundred -- three  hundred -- four hundred -- and fifty.  Now sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabs money and signs) Here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. So long, Hildy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing him) So long, nothing! Where's Bruce  Baldwin's wallet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of that innocent stuff, you  double-crossing hyena! You stuck  Bruce Baldwin in jail this afternoon  on a phony charge that he swiped  your watch, and you frisked his  wallet! Now, give me that wallet or  I'll stick you in jail and it won't  be on any phony charge either! It'll  be for life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't get excited, Hildy! I don't  know what you're talking about --  but is this Mr. Baldwin's wallet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes Bruce's wallet out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing it) You know it is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't frisk him. He must have  dropped it in Burns' office. I didn't  know whose it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- and you don't know that your  cheap boss has had Mr. Baldwin  arrested again -- do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) What -- already? Why, the dame left  only a minute before I did!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly realizes what he's said and sprints for the d Hildy chucks something at him. It just misses as he ducks out of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy casts a savage look after the departed Louie, takes another look at the clock and grabs a phone and starts to dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) 27th Precinct Station House?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy stops short, arrested by a sound from the open wind She turns and sees Earl Williams, looking more inoffensiv and exhausted than ever, indeed on the verge of collapse. carries a large revolver. The search-lights that have bee playing in the courtyard strike into the windows again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing gun at her) Drop that phone --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy drops the phone back on the hook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (supporting himself  by holding on to  edge of desk) You're not going to phone anybody  where I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bracing herself) Put down that gun, Earl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He advances steadily toward Hildy, the gun aimed at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to shoot me, Earl.  I'm your friend, remember? I've got  to write that story about your  "Production for Use".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- that's right. Production for  use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy starts walking toward him, slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earl, you don't want to hurt your  friends, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't move!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you're my friend and maybe  you're not -- but don't come any  nearer. You can't trust anybody in  this crazy world. Say, I'll bet I  could shoot you from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you could, Earl -- but you  wouldn't want to do that, would you?  You wouldn't want to kill anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, you're right. I don't want  to kill anybody. All I want to do is  be let alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy sneaks another step forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earl, there's just one thing I ought  to clear up for the interview.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that? Only -- you're getting  too near. I don't trust anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't blame you, Earl. (another step forward) If I were in your place I wouldn't  trust anybody, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Keep away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points the gun at Hildy, pulls the trigger and we hear faint "click!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) I guess I used all the shells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops the gun and clutches at the edge of the desk for support. Hildy lurches forward and she grabs the other si of the desk for support. And at this moment she looks mor tired than he does. She looks at Earl and breathes heavil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earl, you must never do that again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm awful tired. I couldn't go  through another day like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more her old self  now) Well, maybe you think I could!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS HER as she retrieves the gun and jams it i her purse, jumps to the windows, pulls down the shades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid to die. I was tellin'  the fella that when he handed me the  gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy crosses swiftly to the door, locks it and puts out lights, so that they are visible only faintly in the ligh from the areaway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk too loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (babbling on as she  moves about) Wakin' me up in the middle of the  night -- talkin' to me about things  they don't understand. Callin' me a  Bolshevik. I'm an anarchist. It's  got nothin' to do with bombs. It's  the philosophy that guarantees every  man freedom. You see that, don't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I do, Earl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy is looking around for a hiding place for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish they'd take me back and hang  me. I done my best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He abruptly crumples and falls to the floor. Hildy stands for a second, desperate. Then she picks him up and half  carries, half drags him over toward a chair and places hi in it. Then she makes a quick dash for her phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello... Gimme Walter Burns -- quick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another phone there rings. Hildy answers it, propping the receiver of her own phone between ear and shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into second phone) Hello -- hel -- Oh, hello, Bruce...  Oh, Bruce, please -- I know I said  I'd be down in fifteen minutes, but  something terrific's happened! Hang  on, Bruce -- (into first phone) Walter?... Hildy. Come over here --  right away!... Wait! (into second phone) Bruce, just a second, Bruce -- I'll  explain everything. (into first phone) Walter! Get this: I've got Earl  Williams... Yes! Here in the Press  Room... Honest! On the level. Hurry --  I need you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up and turns into second phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce, this is the biggest thing  that ever happened... (lowers voice) I just captured Earl Williams -- you  know -- the murderer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knocking on the door, but she doesn't hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce, I'll be down -- Well, Bruce,  the minute I turn him over to the  paper I'll be right down. Bruce,  don't you -- Bruce, I can't now -- I  can't, don't you realize?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a click from the phone. He has hung up. Hildy  dejectedly hangs up the phone. There is the sound of knoc on the door. She springs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: taking in door. Hildy glares apprehensively, then crosses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cautiously) Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me, Mollie Malloy! Let me in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy carefully unlocks the door. Mollie bounds in like a wildcat and seizes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they gone? You know where  they are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, Mollie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She manages to relock the door, then turns, leaning again it, facing Mollie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got him surrounded some place --  gonna shoot him like a dog!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mollie, they haven't got him. You  gotta help me, Mollie! We've got to  do something!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a sound -- a groan -- as Williams starts to come to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spinning around) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet, Mollie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's somethin' funny going on  around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mollie crosses to wall and switches on the lights. She se Williams, sobs and rushes over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mollie gets down on her knees and begins ministering to E He opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mollie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mollie begins to sob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy comes over and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet, Mollie, quiet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting out hand to  stroke her hair) Don't cry, Mollie, there's nothing  to cry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get here, Earl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down the drainpipe. I didn't mean to  shoot him. You believe me, don't  you, Mollie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming up) Of course I believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot to thank you for those roses.  They were beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right, Mr. Williams... (to Hildy) You're a woman. You got to help us.  You got to get him out of here, some  place where I can take care of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop screaming, Mollie or we're sunk.  I'm trying to think of something  before those reporters get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let 'em take me. It's better that  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I'll never let 'em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is tried outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll get him! They'll get him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Endicott at door is trying to get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who locked the door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Just a second, Mike --- (whispering to Mollie) Mollie, I got it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy jumps in to the desk and opens it, turning to cry i tense whisper to Earl:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you get in this desk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson is there too, now, and he and Endicott are poundin on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mollie and Earl are with Hildy in front of desk now. They are speaking in whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What good'll it do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get you out in ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open up there, will you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying) All right -- all right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Earl) Go on! (shoving him to desk) Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll find me anyhow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is further and louder pounding on the door. Earl ge in the desk. Hildy and Mollie pull the roll-top down over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) I'm coming! (to Earl) Keep dead quiet. Don't even breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Earl) I'll be right here. I won't leave  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving door a terrific  kick) Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mollie) Mollie, drop down here! You've  fainted!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind! Just play dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy rapidly unbuttons Mollie's waist and throws it back The kicking at the door continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy rushes over to windows and pulls up the shades. Mol is lying quietly on the floor with her eyes closed. Hildy rushes over to water cooler and gets a paper cup full of  water. She throws the water in Mollie's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spluttering) Hey --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fiercely) Shut up, you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy crosses swiftly to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens in Endicott's face and there is Miss Johns quite cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of exclusive, ain't you? We got  calls to make, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run down and get some smelling salts,  will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smelling salts! What's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They catch sight of Mollie, stretched out on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mollie Malloy -- what happened to  her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Endicott and Wilson  enter room) Came up here -- had hysterics and  passed out. I've been trying to get  her to come to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mollie is shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks as though she's going to  come to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a hand with her, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. (lifting Mollie) Up you go, Mollie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hildy and Endicott lift Mollie and seat her in a chair. W crosses to his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into Phone) City Desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking in Hildy, Wilson and Mollie and Endicott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be all right. (crosses to his phone) The Desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Well, they surrounded the house, all  right, only they forgot to tell  Williams, and he wasn't there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing Hildy, who  has been fastening  Mollie's blouse) Hildy, I thought you were gone --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- I was going, but Mollie  fainted away and I thought I ought  to do what I could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some Hallowe'en goin' on outside.  The whole police force standing on  it's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy crosses to his phone. McCue comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panting) What a chase!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) No luck on Williams, yet -- call you  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.
